title: Sampling from mixture distributions based on regime-switching diffusions

sections.text:
#### Abstract

It is proposed to use stochastic differential equations with state-dependent switching rates (SDEwS) for sampling from finite mixture distributions. An Euler scheme with constant time step for SDEwS is considered. It is shown that the scheme converges with order one in weak sense and also in the ergodic limit. Numerical experiments illustrate the use of SDEwS for sampling from mixture distributions and confirm the theoretical results.


Key words. Stochastic differential equations with switching, hybrid switching diffusions, finite mixture distributions, ergodic limits, sampling, weak numerical schemes.

MSC codes. 65C30, 60H35, 60H10, 37H10

1. Introduction. The main theme of this paper is to answer the question how to sample from a finite mixture distribution using stochastic differential equations (SDEs). Mixture distributions are probability distributions which can be written as a superposition of component distributions. They are widely used in statistical modelling and Bayesian inference arising, for instance, in biology (e.g., population modelling, modelling DNA content, etc.), engineering (e.g., modelling failures or defects in complex manufacturing systems); image segmentation, clustering, financial application and many others (see e.g. $[7,3,5]$ ). Efficient sampling algorithms from mixture distributions is of substantial practical importance while it is a challenging problem.

For the last 30 years a lot of attention has been paid how to use SDEs for efficient sampling from Gibbs distributions with densities proportional to $\exp (-U(x))$ with $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ or $x \in D \subset \mathbb{R}^{d}$ or on Riemannian manifolds (see $[31,26,25,17,23,2]$ and references therein). Despite applicable importance of mixture distributions, an SDEs'based approach has not been considered for sampling from mixture distributions.

A natural SDEs' candidate for this sampling task is regime-switching diffusions, in which the SDEs solution interacts with conditionally Markov chain [19, 21, 14, 37]. As we show via a Fokker-Planck equation argument (see Section 2), to sample from a mixture distribution, one needs to consider SDEs with state-dependent switching rates (SDEwS). At the same time, most of the stochastic numerics literature on SDEwS has dealt with constant switching rates only, except the works [38, 36, 28, 37]. As far as we are aware, in previous works proofs of weak-sense convergence and convergence to ergodic limits for numerical approximations for SDEwS were conducted predominately via first proving mean-square (strong) convergence which then implies weak convergence - the route that has been typically avoided for usual SDEs, where instead the link between SDEs and second-order linear parabolic and elliptic PDEs was successfully used (see e.g. [20, 22, 29, 31, 25, 17, 23]). In particular, the PDE route allows to prove an optimal weak-sense order of convergence - this approach is exploited in this paper.

Although our main interest is in sampling from a finite mixture distribution, we also consider finite-time weak-sense convergence for approximations of SDEwS with

[^0]
[^0]:    *School of Mathematical Sciences, University of Nottingham, Nottingham, UK (Michael Tretyakov@nottingham.ac.uk)

    Funding: The author was partially supported by Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC) grant no. EP/X022617/1.

state-dependent switching rates. To this end, we recall that SDEwS find applications in mathematical modelling of biological and ecological processes, in financial mathematics, economics, wireless communications, physics, chemistry and engineering (see such examples e.g. in $[14,37,8]$ and references therein), for which weak-sense approximation is of practical interest. The proof of finite-time weak convergence exploits the backward Kolmogorov equation allowing to achieve an optimal weak-sense order of convergence.

In this paper we use an explicit Euler scheme with constant time stepping for approximating SDEwS as a primer to illustrate the main concepts. It is not difficult to consider other schemes and the proof technique (due to its universality) for weak convergence presented here can be applied to them. We consider the case of SDEwS with globally Lipschitz coefficients for simplicity of the exposition. SDEwS with nonglobally Lipschitz coefficients can be treated either by adapting the concept of rejecting exploding trajectories from SDEs [24, 25, 23] to SDEwS or by exploiting implicit schemes (see e.g. [13]) or tamed/balanced schemes as in the case of usual SDEs (see e.g. [34, 9, 23]), which could be a topic for a future work.

Structure of the rest of the paper is as follows. In Section 2 we introduce SDEwS and the corresponding backward and forward Kolmogorov equations. Then we derive SDEwS suitable for sampling from a given mixture distribution. In Section 3 we write a numerical method and state its properties: weak order of convergence is equal to one and in the ergodic case convergence to ergodic limits in time step is also of order one. In Section 4 we present results of numerical experiments. Proofs of the convergence results are given in Section 5.
2. SDEs with switching. Let $\mathcal{M}=\left\{1, \ldots, m_{0}\right\}$ and introduce the matrix

$$
Q(x)=\left[\begin{array}{cccc}
-q_{1}(x) & q_{12}(x) & \cdots & q_{1 m_{0}}(x) \\
q_{21}(x) & -q_{2}(x) & \cdots & q_{2 m_{0}}(x) \\
\vdots & \vdots & \cdot & \vdots \\
q_{m_{0} 1}(x) & q_{m_{0} 2}(x) & \cdots & -q_{m_{0}}(x)
\end{array}\right], x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}
$$

where $q_{i}(x)$ and $q_{i j}(x)$ are continuous non-negative functions bounded in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and the following relations hold:

$$
\sum_{j \neq i} q_{i j}(x)=q_{i}(x), \quad i \in \mathcal{M}
$$

Consider the SDEwS

$$
d X=a(t, X(t), \mu(t)) d t+\sigma(t, X(t), \mu(t)) d w, \quad X\left(t_{0}\right)=x, \mu\left(t_{0}\right)=m
$$

where $X$ and $a$ are $d$-dimensional column-vectors, $\sigma$ is a $d \times d$-matrix, $w(t)=\left(w_{1}(t)\right.$, $\left.\ldots, w_{d}(t)\right)^{\top}$ is a $d$-dimensional standard Wiener process, and $\mu(t)$ is a one-dimensional continuous-time conditionally Markov process with right-continuous sample paths taking values in $\mathcal{M}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P(\mu(t+\delta)=i \mid \mu(t)=j, X(t)=x)=q_{i j}(x) \delta+o(\delta), i \neq j \\
& P(\mu(t+\delta)=i \mid \mu(t)=i, X(t)=x)=1-q_{i}(x) \delta+o(\delta)
\end{aligned}
$$

provided $\delta \downarrow 0$. The Wiener process $w(t)$ and the exponential clock governing transitions of $\mu(t)$ are independent.

We note that, using Skorokhod's representation (see e.g. [27, p. 104] and [37, p. 29] and [28]), the process $\mu(t)$ can be expressed in terms of the Poisson random measure in the following way. First, introduce the sequence of consecutive, left-closed, right-open intervals $\Gamma_{i j}(x)$ for each $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}: \Gamma_{i i}(x)=\varnothing$ and for $i \neq j$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \Gamma_{i j}(x)=\varnothing \text { if } q_{i j}(x)=0 \\
& \Gamma_{i j}(x)=\left[\sum_{l=i}^{j-1} q_{l}(x)+\sum_{l=1, l \neq i}^{j-1} q_{i l}(x), \sum_{l=i}^{j-1} q_{l}(x)+\sum_{l=1, l \neq i}^{j} q_{i l}(x)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Each non empty $\Gamma_{i i}(x)$ has length $q_{i j}(x)$. Next, define the function $F: \mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{M} \times \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}$

$$
F(x, i, z):=\sum_{j \in \mathcal{M}}(j-i) \mathbb{I}_{\Gamma_{i j}(x)}(z)
$$

Then the process $\mu(t)$ satisfies the SDE

$$
d \mu(t)=\int_{[0, L]} F(X(t), \mu(t-), z) N(d t, d z)
$$

where $L=m_{0}\left(m_{0}-1\right) \ell$ with $\ell=\max _{i \in \mathcal{M}} \sup _{x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}} q_{i}(x)$ and $N(d t, d z)$ is a Poisson random measure with intensity $d t \times v(d z)$ and $v(d z)$ being the Lebesgue measure on $[0, L]$. The Poisson random measure $N(\cdot, \cdot)$ is independent of the Wiener process $w(\cdot)$.

The solution of (2.3), (2.4) is a Markov process $(X, \mu)$ with the infinitesimal generator acting on functions $g \in C^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d} \times \mathcal{M}\right)$ (see [21] and [37, p. 28]):

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal{L} g(x ; m):=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{l, k=1}^{d} & \sigma_{l k}(t, x, m) \sigma_{l k}(t, x, m) \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{l} \partial x^{k}} g(x ; m)+\sum_{l=1}^{d} a^{l}(t, x, m) \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{j}} g(x ; m) \\
& -q_{m}(x) g(x ; m)+\sum_{j \neq m} q_{m j}(x) g(x ; j), \quad m \in \mathcal{M}
\end{aligned}
$$

The Cauchy problem for the system of linear parabolic PDEs (the backward Kolmogorov equation)

$$
\begin{gathered}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(t, x ; m)+\mathcal{L} u(t, x ; m)=0, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, t<T \\
u(T, x ; m)=\varphi(x ; m), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \\
m \in \mathcal{M}
\end{gathered}
$$

has the probabilistic representation [21] (see also [37, p. 52]):

$$
u(t, x ; m)=E \varphi\left(X_{t, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{t, x, m}(T)\right)
$$

where $\left(X_{t, x, m}(s), \mu_{t, x, m}(s)\right), s \geq t$, is a solution of (2.3), (2.4) and $\varphi(x ; m)$ are sufficiently smooth functions with growth not faster than polynomial (we provide precise assumptions for convergence theorems in the next section).

The adjoint operator $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ to $\mathcal{L}$ acting on sufficiently smooth functions $\rho(x ; m)$ is:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho(x ; m):=\frac{1}{2} \sum_{l, k=1}^{d} \frac{\partial^{2}}{\partial x^{l} \partial x^{k}}\left(\sigma_{l k}(x, m) \sigma_{l k}(x, m) \rho(x ; m)\right) \\
-\sum_{l=1}^{d} \frac{\partial}{\partial x^{l}}\left(a^{l}(x, m) \rho(x ; m)\right)-q_{m}(x) \rho(x ; m)+\sum_{j \neq m} q_{j m}(x) \rho(x ; j), \quad m \in \mathcal{M}
\end{gathered}
$$

Consequently, the Fokker-Planck equation (forward Kolmogorov equation) takes the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \rho(t, x ; m) & =\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho(t, x ; m), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, t>t_{0} \\
\rho\left(t_{0}, x ; m\right) & =\delta\left(x-x_{0}\right) \delta_{m, i}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, m \in \mathcal{M}
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\sum_{m=1}^{m_{0}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \rho(t, x ; m)=1
$$

Here, $\{\rho(t, x ; j)\}_{j=1}^{m_{0}}$ gives the density for $\left(X_{t_{0}, x_{0}, i}(t) ; \mu_{t_{0}, x_{0}, i}(t)\right)$.
2.1. Ergodic case. Let $U(x ; m) \geq 0, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, m \in \mathcal{M}$, be sufficiently smooth functions. Consider a given finite mixture distribution with sufficiently smooth density

$$
\rho(x)=\frac{1}{\mathcal{Z}} \sum_{m=1}^{m_{0}} \rho(x ; m)
$$

where

$$
\rho(x ; m)=\alpha_{m} \exp (-U(x ; m))
$$

$\alpha_{m}>0$ are weights, and the normalisation constant $\mathcal{Z}$ :

$$
\mathcal{Z}=\sum_{m=1}^{m_{0}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \rho(x ; m) d x
$$

As highlighted in the Introduction, mixture distributions are commonly employed in statistical modelling and Bayesian inference.

Assumption 2.1. The elements $q_{i j}(x), i \neq j$, of the matrix $Q(x)$ are positive Hölder continuous functions for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and they are bounded in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$. The functions $U(x ; m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, are twice differentiable and for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $m \in \mathcal{M}$ :

$$
-\nabla U(x ; m) \cdot x \leq-c_{1}|x|^{2}+c_{2}
$$

where $c_{1}>0$ and $c_{2} \in \mathbb{R}$.
Introduce the SDEwS

$$
d X=-\frac{1}{2} \nabla U(X, \mu(t)) d t+d w(t), \quad X(0)=x, \mu(0)=m
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P(\mu(t+\delta)=i \mid \mu(t)=j, X(t)=x)=q_{i j}(x) \delta+o(\delta), i \neq j \\
& P(\mu(t+\delta)=i \mid \mu(t)=i, X(t)=x)=1-q_{i}(x) \delta+o(\delta)
\end{aligned}
$$

under $\delta \downarrow 0$.
We recall $[10$, p. 117] that we say that a process $Z(t)=(X(t), \mu(t))$ is ergodic if there exists a unique invariant measure $\pi$ of $Z$ and independently of $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $m \in \mathcal{M}$ there exists the limit

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} E \varphi\left(X_{x, m}(t) ; \mu_{x, m}(t)\right)=\sum_{j=1}^{m_{0}} \int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \varphi(x ; j) \pi(d x, j):=\varphi^{e r g}
$$

for any function $\varphi(x ; m)$ with polynomial growth at infinity in $x$; and we say that a process $Z(t)$ is exponentially ergodic if for any $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ and $m \in \mathcal{M}$ and any function $\varphi$ with a polynomial growth in $x$

$$
\left|E \varphi\left(X_{x, m}(t) ; \mu_{x, m}(t)\right)-\varphi^{e r g}\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) e^{-\lambda t}, \quad t \geq 0
$$

where $C>0$ and $\lambda>0$ are some constants.
Under Assumption 2.1, the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) is exponentially ergodic with $X(t)$ having (in the ergodic limit) a smooth density $\rho(x)=\sum_{m=1}^{m_{0}} \rho(x ; m)$ (see e.g. $[33,4,35]$ and also [37, Sections 4.2 and 4.5]), where $\rho(x ; m)$ satisfy the stationary Fokker-Planck equations

$$
\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho(x ; m)=0, \quad m \in \mathcal{M}
$$

Here the adjoint operator $\mathcal{L}^{*}$ (cf. (2.8)) is
$\mathcal{L}^{*} \rho(x ; m)=\frac{1}{2} \Delta \rho(x ; m)+\frac{1}{2} \nabla \cdot(\rho(x ; m) \nabla U(x ; m))-q_{m}(x) \rho(x ; m)+\sum_{j \neq m} q_{j m}(x) \rho(x ; j)$.
Now let us consider how to use the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) for sampling from the mixture distribution (2.11). It is not difficult to check that the functions $\rho(x ; m)$ from (2.11) satisfy (2.17) if they solve the following system

$$
-q_{m}(x) \rho(x ; m)+\sum_{j \neq m} q_{j m}(x) \rho(x ; j)=0, m \in \mathcal{M}
$$

or equivalently

$$
\sum_{j \neq m}\left[q_{j m}(x) \rho(x ; j)-q_{m j}(x) \rho(x ; m)\right]=0, m \in \mathcal{M}
$$

which is satisfied if for $j \neq m$

$$
\frac{q_{j m}(x)}{q_{m j}(x)}=\frac{\rho(x ; m)}{\rho(x ; j)}
$$

Thus, we arrived at the proposition.
Proposition 2.2. Let Assumption 2.1 hold for the functions $U(x, m)$ and for the matrix $Q(x)$ satisfying (2.18). Then the solution $\left(X_{0, x, m}(t) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(t)\right)$ of the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) with $Q(x)$ satisfying (2.18) has the unique invariant measure $\rho(x)$ from (2.10), (2.11).

We remark that a choice of functions $q_{j m}(x)$ satisfying (2.18) is not unique. For instance, we can choose

$$
q_{j m}(x)=\rho(x ; m)
$$

or

$$
q_{j m}(x)=\frac{\rho(x ; m)}{\beta_{m} \beta_{j}}
$$

for some $\beta_{m}>0$, etc. We emphasise that as in all Markov chain-type samplers we do not need to know the normalisation constant $\mathcal{Z}$ of the targeted distribution, we

only need to know relative weights of the mixture components. We note that under Assumption 2.1 both choices (2.19) and (2.20) guarantee boundedness and positivity of $q_{j m}(x)$. Functions $q_{j m}(x)$ are related to how fast $\left(X_{0, x, m}(t) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(t)\right)$ converges to its ergodic limit. Finding an optimal choice of $Q(x)$ satisfying (2.18) is an interesting theoretical and practical question which we leave for future study.

Proposition 2.2 ascertain that the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) with $Q(x)$ satisfying (2.18) can be utilised for sampling from mixture distributions (2.10), (2.11). In the next section we construct a Markov chain approximating the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) and show that it can approximate associated ergodic limits.

We note that in the case of the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14), the backward Kolmogorov equation (2.6) takes the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\partial}{\partial t} u(t, x ; m)+\mathcal{L} u(t, x ; m) & =0, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, t<T \\
u(T, x ; m) & =\varphi(x ; m), x \in \mathbb{R}^{d} \\
m & \in \mathcal{M}
\end{aligned}
$$

where
$\mathcal{L} g(x ; m):=\frac{1}{2} \Delta g(x ; m)-\frac{1}{2} \nabla U(x ; m) \cdot \nabla g(x ; m)-q_{m}(x) g(x ; m)+\sum_{j \neq m} q_{m j}(x) g(x ; j)$.
3. Numerical method, estimators and their properties. In Section 3.1 we consider an Euler method for the SDEwS (2.3), (2.4) and state a theorem on its weak convergence with order one. In Section 3.2 we apply the Euler method to the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) and state error estimates for ensemble averaging and time averaging estimators of ergodic limits corresponding to a mixture distribution.

Introduce the equidistant partition of the time interval $[0, T]$ into $N$ parts with the step $h=T / N: t_{0}<t_{1}<\cdots<t_{N}=T, t_{k+1}-t_{k}=h$.

We recall and adapt to SDEwS the following definitions [23, Chap. 2].
Definition 3.1. A function $f(x)$ belongs to the class $\mathbf{F}$ if there are constants $K>0, \kappa>0$ such that for all $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ the following inequality holds:

$$
|f(x)| \leq K\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)
$$

If a function $f(x ; s)$ depends not only on $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$ but also on a parameter $s \in S$, then $f(x ; s)$ belongs to $\mathbf{F}$ (with respect to the variable $x$ ) if an inequality of the type (3.1) holds uniformly in $s \in S$.

Definition 3.2. If an approximation $(\bar{X}, \bar{\mu})$ of the solution $(X, \mu)$ to (2.3), (2.4) is such that for $p>0$

$$
|E f(\bar{X}(T) ; \bar{\mu}(T))-E f(X(T) ; \mu(T))| \leq C h^{p}
$$

for $f \in \mathbf{F}$, then we say that the weak order of accuracy of the approximation $(\bar{X}, \bar{\mu})$ is p. The constant $C>0$ may depend on the coefficients of (2.3), (2.4), on the function $f$ and on $T$.

We introduce the following spaces: $C^{\frac{p+q}{2}, p+\epsilon}\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ (or $\left.C^{p+\epsilon}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ is a Hölder space containing functions $f(t, x)$ (or $f(x)$ ) whose partial derivatives $\frac{\partial^{i+j j} f}{\partial t^{i} \partial x^{j} t \cdots \partial x^{j} d}$ (or $\left.\frac{\partial^{i j} f}{\partial x^{j} t \cdots \partial x^{j} d}\right)$ with $0 \leq 2 i+|j|<p+\epsilon$ (or $|j|<p+\epsilon), i \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}, p \in \mathbb{N} \cup\{0\}$,

$0<\epsilon<1, j$ is a multi-index, are continuous in $[0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d}$ (or $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ ) with finite Hölder norm $|\cdot|^{(p+\epsilon)}$ (see e.g. [11, Chap. 1, Sec. 1]). In what follows, for brevity of the notation, we omit $\epsilon$ and write $C^{\frac{p}{2}, p}\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ (or $\left.C^{p}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)\right)$ instead of $C^{\frac{p+q}{2}, p+\epsilon}(\bar{Q})$ (or $\left.C^{p+\epsilon}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)\right)$, which should not lead to any confusion.
3.1. Finite-time case. We prove convergence of the numerical method considered in this section under the following assumption on the coefficients of (2.3), (2.4). At the same time, we note that the method itself can be used when the assumption does not hold and studying this method under weaker assumptions is a possible subject for a future work as discussed in the Introduction.

Assumption 3.3. The coefficients $a(t, x, m)$ and $\sigma(t, x, m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, are $C^{1,2}$ $\left([0, T] \times \mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$ functions with growth not faster than linear when $|x| \rightarrow \infty$; the elements $q_{i j}(x), i \neq j$, of the matrix $Q(x)$ are non-negative functions bounded in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and belong to $C^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$; and the functions $\varphi(x ; m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, and their derivatives $\frac{\partial^{|j|} \varphi}{\partial x^{j 1} \cdots \partial x^{j d}},|j| \leq$ 4 , are continuous and belong to the class $\mathbf{F}$.

Under Assumption 3.3, the solution $u(t, x ; m)$ to the backward Kolmogorov equation (2.6) satisfies the following estimate (see e.g. [11, Chap. 7, Sec. 10, Theorem 10.2] and [6, Chap. 9, Sec. 6, Theorem 11]) for some $\kappa \geq 1$ :

$$
\sum_{l=0}^{4} \sum_{2 i+|j|=l}\left|\frac{\partial^{i+|j|}}{\partial t^{i} \partial x^{j_{1}} \cdots \partial x^{j_{d}}} u(t, x ; m)\right| \leq K\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)
$$

where $j$ is a multi-index and $K>0$ is independent of $x$ and $m$, it may depend on $T$.
We also note that Assumption 3.3 is sufficient for existence of a unique solution of (2.3), (2.4) (see [37, p. 30 and p. 34] and [38] for weaker conditions than Assumption 3.3 which are sufficient for existence of a unique solution of (2.3), (2.4); Assumption 3.3 is used here for proving first-order weak convergence).

Consider the Euler scheme for the SDEwS (2.3), (2.4):

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{0} & =x, \quad \mu_{0}=m \in \mathcal{M} \\
X_{k+1} & =X_{k}+h a\left(t_{k}, X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right)+h^{1 / 2} \sigma\left(t_{k}, X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \xi_{k+1} \\
\mu_{k+1} & =\left\{\begin{array}{l}
j \neq \mu_{k} \text { with } \operatorname{prob} q_{\mu_{k} j}\left(X_{k}\right) h \\
\mu_{k} \text { with } \operatorname{prob} 1-q_{\mu_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right) h
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\xi_{k+1}=\left(\xi_{k+1}^{1}, \ldots, \xi_{k+1}^{d}\right)^{\top}$ and $\xi_{k+1}^{i}$ are i.i.d. random variables with bounded moments and

$$
E \xi_{k+1}^{i}=0, \quad E\left[\left(\xi_{k+1}^{i}\right)^{2}\right]=1, \quad E\left[\left(\xi_{k+1}^{i}\right)^{3}\right]=0
$$

The conditions (3.5) are, e.g. satisfied for normal distribution with zero mean and unit variance or for discrete random variables taking values $\pm 1$ with probability $1 / 2$. The random variables $\xi_{k+1}^{i}$ and the random variable responsible for switching $\mu_{k+1}$ are mutually independent.

The following finite-time weak convergence theorem is proved in Section 5.1 for the scheme (3.4).

THEOREM 3.4. Let Assumption 3.3 hold. Then the scheme (3.4) for the SDEwS (2.3), (2.4) converges with weak order one, i.e.,

$$
\left|E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-E \varphi\left(X_{t, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{t, x, m}(T)\right)\right| \leq C h\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)
$$

where $C>0$ and $\kappa \geq 1$ are independent of $h$.

Remark 3.5. Since the proof of Theorem 3.4 utilises closeness of the semi-groups associated to the SDEwS (2.3), (2.4) and the Euler scheme (3.4), it is essentially universal like all weak-sense convergence proofs of this type (see e.g. [23, Chap. 2]) and can be extended to other weak schemes for (2.3), (2.4). E.g., it is of interest to find a way of constructing second-order weak schemes for SDEs with switching.
3.2. Ergodic case. Now we consider how to approximate ergodic limits associated with the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14). To prove convergence of the considered numerical method to ergodic limit with first order in $h$, we need a stronger assumption than Assumption 2.1.

Assumption 3.6. The functions $U(x, m) \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right), m \in \mathcal{M}$, and satisfy (2.12) and $\nabla U(x, m)$ have growth not faster than linear when $|x| \rightarrow \infty$; the elements $q_{i j}(x)$ of the matrix $Q(x)$ are positive functions bounded in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and belong to $C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$; and the functions $\varphi(x ; m) \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right), m \in \mathcal{M}$, and they and their derivatives belong to the class $\mathbf{F}$.

Similarly how it is proved in [31] for the case of the usual ergodic SDEs, there are constants $K>0, \lambda>0$ and $\kappa \geq 1$ independent of $T, x$ and $m$ such that the following bound holds for the solution $u(t, x ; m)$ to the backward Kolmogorov equation (2.21):

$$
\sum_{l=1}^{4} \sum_{2 i+|j|=l}\left|\frac{\partial^{i+|j|}}{\partial t^{i} \partial x^{j_{1}} \cdots \partial x^{j_{d}}} u(t, x ; m)\right| \leq K\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) e^{-\lambda(T-t)}
$$

where $j$ is a multi-index. We note that under Assumption 3.6 the above estimate is true for any order of derivatives of the solution $u(t, x ; m)$ [31]; we write (3.6) for $2 i+|j| \leq 4$ because it is sufficient for proofs.

In the case of the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14), the Euler scheme (3.4) takes the form

$$
\begin{aligned}
X_{0} & =x, \quad \mu_{0}=m \in \mathcal{M} \\
X_{k+1} & =X_{k}-\frac{h}{2} \nabla U\left(X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right)+h^{1 / 2} \xi_{k+1} \\
\mu_{k+1} & = \begin{cases}j \neq \mu_{k} & \text { with } \operatorname{prob} q_{\mu_{k} j}\left(X_{k}\right) h \\
\mu_{k} & \text { with } \operatorname{prob} 1-q_{\mu_{k}}\left(X_{k}\right) h\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\xi_{k+1}$ satisfy (3.5).
Ergodic limits can be computed using ensemble average or time averaging [31, 25, 23]. Ensemble averaging is based on proximity of $E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(T)\right)$ to $\varphi^{\text {erg }}$ for a sufficiently large $T$ (see (2.16)). In practice the expectation $E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)$ approximating $E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(T)\right)$ is realised using the Monte Carlo technique which can benefit from parallel computations on GPUs and multiple CPUs. For faster exploration of the phase space and hence for faster convergence to the ergodic limit, the initial points $x$ and $m$ of the process $\left(X_{0, x, m}(t), \mu_{0, x, m}(t)\right)$ can be taken random using a suitable distribution, e.g. $m$ can be distributed uniformly (see further discussion in [25] in the case of usual SDEs and here in Section 4).

The next theorem gives the error of approximating the ergodic limit using ensembleaveraging, in other words, it gives bias of the ensemble-averaging estimator $\hat{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ for the ergodic limit $\varphi^{\text {erg }}$ defined in (2.15):

$$
\hat{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}=\frac{1}{M} \sum_{k=1}^{M} \varphi\left(X_{N}^{(k)} ; \mu_{N}^{(k)}\right)
$$

where $M$ is the number of independent realizations of $\left(X_{N}, \mu_{N}\right)$. The error estimate is proved in Section 5.2.

THEOREM 3.7. Let Assumption 3.6 hold. Then the scheme (3.7) for the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) converges with order one to the ergodic limit $\varphi^{\text {erg }}$, i.e.,

$$
\left|E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-\varphi^{\text {erg }}\right| \leq C\left[h+\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) \exp (-\lambda T)\right]
$$

where $C>0, \kappa \geq 1$ and $\lambda>0$ are independent of $h, T$ and $x ; C$ and $\kappa$ depend on the choice of $\varphi(x ; m)$.

We note that this theorem and its proof hold if instead of positivity of all elements of the matrix $Q(x)$ (see Assumption 3.6), we assume that they are nonnegative and $Q(x)$ is irreducible for every $x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$. We keep the positivity assumption in the view of Proposition 2.2 and that the key objective of this paper is to address the problem of sampling from mixture distributions.

Due to ergodicity, we have (see e.g. [10, p. 110])

$$
\lim _{t \rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{t} \int_{0}^{t} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s=\varphi^{\text {erg }} \text { a.s. }
$$

Then for a sufficiently large $\tilde{T}$ :

$$
\varphi^{\text {erg }} \approx \frac{1}{\tilde{T}} \int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s \approx \tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}:=\frac{1}{L} \sum_{l=1}^{L} \varphi\left(X_{l} ; \mu_{l}\right)
$$

It follows from (2.16) that the bias of the estimator $\frac{1}{T} \int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s$ is of order $O(1 / \tilde{T})$ :

$$
\left|E\left(\frac{1}{\tilde{T}} \int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s\right)-\varphi^{\text {erg }}\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) \frac{1}{\tilde{T}}
$$

where $C>0$ is independent of $\tilde{T}, x$ and $m$.
THEOREM 3.8. Let Assumption 3.6 hold. Then the bias of the estimator $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ has the error estimate

$$
\left|E \tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}-\varphi^{\text {erg }}\right| \leq C\left(h+\frac{1+|x|^{\kappa}}{\tilde{T}}\right)
$$

where $C>0$ and $\kappa \geq 1$ are independent of $h, x$, and $\tilde{T} ; C$ and $\kappa$ depend on the choice of $\varphi(x ; m)$.

Both estimators $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ and $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ have the three errors: numerical integration error controlled by the time step $h$ (and in general by a choice of numerical method too); the variance which is controlled by the number of independent realisations $M$ in the case of the ensemble-averaging estimator $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ and by the time $\tilde{T}=L h$ in the case of $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$; and error due to proximity to the stationary distribution which is controlled by the integration time $T=N h$ for $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$ and by $\tilde{T}=L h$ for $\tilde{\varphi}^{\text {erg }}$.

Remark 3.9. Let us briefly compare the two estimators. First, it is not difficult to establish that

$$
\left|E \hat{\varphi}^{e r g}-E \hat{\varphi}^{e r g}\right| \leq C\left(h+\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)\left[\frac{1}{\hat{T}}+\exp (-\lambda T)\right]\right)
$$

where $C>0$ is independent of $h, x, T$, and $\hat{T}$. Next, the computational cost of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ is proportional to $N M$ and of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g} \propto L$. Since the variance (which is just the Monte Carlo error) of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ is $\mathcal{O}(1 / M)$, the mean-square error of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ is (see, e.g. [23, Sec. 2.5.2]) $\sqrt{E\left[\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}-\varphi^{e r g}\right]^{2}}=\mathcal{O}(1 / \sqrt{M}+h+\exp (-\lambda N h))$, where we used Theorem 3.7. Since the variance of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ is $\mathcal{O}(1 / L h)$ (see [17] and Remark 5.5), the mean-square error of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ is $\mathcal{O}(1 / \sqrt{L h}+h)$, where we used Theorem 3.8. Consequently, if we fix a tolerance level $\varepsilon>0$ for the mean-square errors, then the cost of reaching this level is $\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-3} \log (1 / \varepsilon)\right)$ for $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ and $\mathcal{O}\left(\varepsilon^{-3}\right)$ for $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ if we optimally choose $h \propto \varepsilon$, $M \propto \varepsilon^{-2}, N \propto \varepsilon^{-1} \log (1 / \varepsilon)$ and $L \propto \varepsilon^{-3}$. Traditionally, in statistics and molecular dynamics, time-averaging estimators have been used. However, with growing availability of servers with multiple CPUs and powerful GPU cards, the ensemble-averaging estimators are becoming more attractive because they perfectly suit parallel computing. We remark that the discussed complexity is asymptotic and constants in the error estimates can play an important role for computational efficiency of the estimators. From this angle and as discussed before, we note that the initial condition $\left(X_{0}, \mu_{0}\right)$ can be taken random to speed up convergence of $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ to $\varphi^{e r g}$, i.e. reduce the constant in front of $\exp (-\lambda T)$ in the error estimate (see e.g. such a discussion in [25]).
4. Numerical experiments. We conduct experiments with the ensemble-averaging estimator $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ which allows to fully benefit from parallel computing. The Monte Carlo error presented for the ensemble-averaging estimator $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ in this section is given as usual by $2 \sqrt{\hat{D}_{M} / M}$ with

$$
\hat{D}_{M}=\frac{1}{M} \sum_{m=1}^{M}\left[\varphi\left(X_{N}^{(k)} ; \mu_{N}^{(k)}\right)\right]^{2}-\left[\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}\right]^{2}
$$

We test the first-order of weak convergence of the scheme (3.7) on sampling from a univariate Gaussian mixture with two components, a mixture of Gaussian and distribution with nonconvex potential, and a multivariate Gaussian mixture. In all the experiments, we use the choice (2.19) and we uniformly distribute the initial state $\mu(0)$ and take $X(0)$ equal to the mean of the $\mu(0)$ th component in the mixture.

5.1. Finite-time convergence. The proof of the next lemma on boundedness of moments of the Euler scheme under weaker conditions than Assumption 3.3 can be found e.g. in [36, Lemma 3.1].

Lemma 5.1. Let Assumption 3.3 hold. Then the method (3.4) has finite moments, i.e., for all $p \geq 1$ :

$$
E\left(\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}\right) \leq K\left(1+|x|^{2 p}\right)
$$

where $K>0$ does not depend on $h$ and $x$.
The following error gives the one-step error estimate.
Lemma 5.2. Let Assumption 3.3 hold. Then the one-step error of the method (3.4) is estimated as

$$
\left|E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; \mu_{1}\right)-u(t, x ; m)\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\varkappa}\right) h^{2}
$$

where $u(t+h, x, m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, is a solution of (2.6), $C>0$ and $\varkappa \geq 1$ do not depend

![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

on $h, x$ and $m$.

Proof. Using Taylor's expansion, the conditions (3.5), and the backward Kolmogorov

equation (2.6), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \text { (5.1) } \quad E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; \mu_{1}\right)-u(t, x ; m) \\
& =h \sum_{j \neq m} q_{m j}(x) E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; j\right)+\left(1-h q_{m}(x)\right) E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; m\right)-u(t, x ; m) \\
& =h \sum_{j \neq m} q_{m j}(x) u(t, x ; j)-h q_{m}(x) u(t, x ; m)+E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; m\right) \\
& \quad-u(t, x ; m)+r_{1}(t, x) \\
& =h \mathcal{L} u(t, x ; m)+r_{2}(t, x)=r_{2}(t, x)
\end{aligned}
$$

where $r_{1}$ is a combination of first order derivative in time and first and second order derivatives in space of $u$ multiplied by corresponding $q_{i j}$ and the coefficients of (2.3); $r_{2}$ in addition contains a combination of $\frac{\partial f^{+(i)}{ }_{n}}{\partial l^{i} \partial x^{i} ; \ldots \partial x^{i} d}$ with $l=0,|i|=2,3,4 ; l=1$, $|i|=1,2 ; l=2,|i|=0$ appropriately multiplied by the coefficients of (2.3); and, thanks to Assumption 3.3 and the estimate (3.3), the reminders are estimated as

$$
\left|r_{i}(t, x)\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\varkappa}\right) h^{2}
$$

Proof of Theorem 3.4. We re-write the global error using the Feynman-Kac formula (2.7):

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-E \varphi\left(X_{t, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{t, x, m}(T)\right)\right|=\left|E u\left(t_{N}, X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-u(t, x ; m)\right| \\
& =\left|E \sum_{k=0}^{N-1}\left(u\left(t_{k+1}, X_{k+1} ; \mu_{k+1}\right)-u\left(t_{k}, X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right)\right)\right| \\
& =\left|\sum_{k=0}^{N-1} E\left(E\left[u\left(t_{k+1}, X_{k+1} ; \mu_{k+1}\right)-u\left(t_{k}, X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right) \mid X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right]\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} E\left|E\left[u\left(t_{k+1}, X_{k+1} ; \mu_{k+1}\right)-u\left(t_{k}, X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right) \mid X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right]\right| \leq C h^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} E\left(1+\left|X_{k+1}\right|^{\varkappa}\right) \\
& \leq C h\left(1+|x|^{\varkappa}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we applied Lemmas 5.1 and 5.2 .
5.2. Ergodic limits convergence. We start with proving an estimate for the moments of the method (3.7).

Lemma 5.3. Let Assumption 3.6 hold. Then the method (3.7) has finite moments, i.e., for sufficiently small $h>0$ and all $p \geq 1$ :

$$
E\left(\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}\right) \leq K\left(1+|x|^{2 p} e^{-\lambda t_{k}}\right)
$$

where $K>0$ does not depend on $h, T$ and $x$.
Proof. We note that the constant $K>0$ is changing from line to line. We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& E\left|X_{k+1}\right|^{2 p} \leq E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+p E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-2}\left[2\left(X_{k} \cdot\left(X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right)\right)+(2 p-1)\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{2}\right] \\
& \quad+K \sum_{l=3}^{2 p} E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-l}\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{l}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $K>0$ depends on $p$ only. Using that $|\nabla U(x ; m)| \leq K(1+|x|)$, (3.5) and (2.12), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
E\left[X_{k} \cdot\left(X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right) \mid X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right] & \leq-\frac{h}{2} X_{k} \cdot \nabla U\left(X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right) \leq-\frac{h}{2} c_{1}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2}+\frac{h}{2} c_{2} \\
E\left[\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{2} \mid X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right] & \leq K h^{2}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2}+h \\
E\left[\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{l} \mid X_{k}, \mu_{k}\right] & \leq K h^{l}\left|X_{k}\right|^{l}+K h^{l / 2}, l \geq 3
\end{aligned}
$$

with $K>0$ independent of $h$.
Then, using Young's inequality (i.e., for $y, z \geq 0: y z \leq \epsilon^{i} \frac{z^{i}}{i}+\epsilon^{-j} \frac{z^{j}}{j}$ with $\epsilon>0$, $i, j>1$ and $\frac{1}{i}+\frac{1}{j}=1$ ), we get (where needed with a new $K>0$ independent of $h$ ):

$$
\begin{gathered}
2 p E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-2}\left(X_{k} \cdot\left(X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right)\right) \leq-p c_{1} h E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+p h K E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-2} \\
\leq-p c_{1} h E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+(p-1) c_{1} h \mathbb{E}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+h K^{p}\left(\frac{1}{c_{1}}\right)^{p-1} \\
=-c_{1} h E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+h K^{p}\left(\frac{1}{c_{1}}\right)^{p-1} \\
p(2 p-1) E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-2}\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{2} \leq p(2 p-1) K h^{2}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+h p(2 p-1) E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-2} \\
\leq K h^{2}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+\frac{c_{1}}{2} h E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+\frac{[(2 p-1)(p-1)]^{p}}{p-1}\left(\frac{2}{c_{1}}\right)^{p-1} h
\end{gathered}
$$

and for $l \geq 3$

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-l}\left|X_{k+1}-X_{k}\right|^{l} \leq K h^{l}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+K h^{l / 2} E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p-l} \\
\leq K h^{l}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+\frac{c_{1} h^{l / 2}}{2 p} \mathbb{E}\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+K h^{l / 2}
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus

$$
E\left|X_{k+1}\right|^{2 p} \leq E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}-\frac{c_{1}}{2} h(1-\sqrt{h}-K h) E\left|X_{k}\right|^{2 p}+K h
$$

whence by Gronwald's lemma

$$
\begin{gathered}
E\left|X_{k+1}\right|^{2 p} \leq\left(1-\frac{c_{1} h}{2}(1-\sqrt{h}-K h)\right)^{k}|x|^{2 p} \\
+\frac{2 K}{c_{1}(1-\sqrt{h}-K h)}\left[1-\left(1-\frac{c_{1} h}{2}(1-\sqrt{h}-K h)\right)^{k}\right]
\end{gathered}
$$

The local error of the method (3.7) is given in the next lemma.
Lemma 5.4. Let Assumption 3.6 hold. Then the one-step error of the method (3.7) is estimated as

$$
\left|E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; \mu_{1}\right)-u(t, x ; m)\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\varkappa}\right) e^{-\lambda(T-t)} h^{2}
$$

where $u(t+h, x, m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, is a solution of (2.21), $C>0$ and $\varkappa \geq 1$ do not depend on $T$ and $h$.

Proof. Analogously to (5.1) but using (2.21), we have

$$
E u\left(t+h, X_{1} ; \mu_{1}\right)-u(t, x ; m)=r_{3}(t, x)
$$

where the reminder $r_{3}(t, x)$ is, analogously to $r_{2}$ in (5.1), a sum of terms containing derivatives of $u$ and the coefficients of the SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) and hence by (3.6)

$$
\left|r_{3}(t, x)\right| \leq C\left(1+|x|^{\varkappa}\right) e^{-\lambda(T-t)} h^{2}
$$

where $C>0$ is independent of $h, t, T$ and $x$.

Proof of Theorem 3.7. Using (2.16) and Lemmas 5.4 and 5.3, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-\varphi^{e r g}\right| \\
\leq & \left|E \varphi\left(X_{N} ; \mu_{N}\right)-E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(T)\right)\right|+\left|E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(T) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(T)\right)-\varphi^{e r g}\right| \\
\leq & \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} E\left|E\left[u\left(t_{k+1}, X_{k+1} ; \mu_{k+1}\right)-u\left(t_{k}, X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right) \mid X_{k} ; \mu_{k}\right]\right|+C\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) e^{-\lambda T} \\
\leq & C h^{2} \sum_{k=0}^{N-1} e^{-\lambda\left(T-t_{k}\right)}\left(1+E\left|X_{k}\right|^{\varkappa}\right)+C\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) e^{-\lambda T} \leq C\left[h+\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) \exp (-\lambda T)\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Theorem 3.8. Thanks to (3.6), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|h \sum_{l=1}^{L} E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right) ; \mu_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right)\right)-\int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s\right| \\
= & \left|h \sum_{l=1}^{L} u\left(0, x ; m ; t_{l}\right)-\int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} u(0, x ; m ; s) d s\right| \\
& =\left|h \sum_{l=1}^{L} u\left(-t_{l}, x ; m ; 0\right)-\int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} u(-s, x ; m ; 0) d s\right| \\
\leq & C h^{2} \sum_{l=1}^{L}\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) e^{-\lambda\left(T-t_{l}\right)} \leq C h\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Theorem 3.7, (5.2) and (3.12), we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|E \hat{\varphi}^{e r g}-\varphi^{e r g}\right| \leq\left|\frac{1}{L} \sum_{l=1}^{L}\left[E \varphi\left(X_{l} ; \mu_{l}\right)-E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right) ; \mu_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right)\right)\right]\right| \\
& +\left|\frac{1}{L} \sum_{l=1}^{L} E \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right) ; \mu_{0, x, m}\left(t_{l}\right)\right)-\frac{1}{\tilde{T}} E \int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s\right| \\
& +\left|\frac{1}{\tilde{T}} E \int_{0}^{\tilde{T}} \varphi\left(X_{0, x, m}(s) ; \mu_{0, x, m}(s)\right) d s-\varphi^{e r g}\right| \\
& \leq \frac{1}{L} \sum_{l=1}^{L} C\left[h+\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) \exp \left(-\lambda t_{l}\right)\right]+C \frac{h}{\tilde{T}}\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)+C\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right) \frac{1}{\tilde{T}} \\
& \leq C\left(h+\frac{1+|x|^{\kappa}}{\tilde{T}}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Remark 5.5. The following system of Poisson equations is associated with SDEwS (2.13), (2.14) with $Q(x)$ satisfying (2.18):

$$
\mathcal{L} u(x ; m)=\varphi(x ; m)-\varphi_{m}^{e r g}, x \in \mathbb{R}^{d}, m \in \mathcal{M}
$$

where $\mathcal{L}$ is as in (2.21) and

$$
\varphi_{m}^{e r g}=\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}} \varphi(x ; m) \rho(x ; m) d x
$$

with $\rho(x ; m)$ from (2.10). If $U(x, m) \in C^{3}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right), m \in \mathcal{M}$, and satisfy (2.12), and the elements $q_{i j}(x)$ of the matrix $Q(x)$ are positive functions bounded in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ and belong to $C^{2}\left(\mathbb{R}^{d}\right)$, and the functions $\varphi(x ; m), m \in \mathcal{M}$, and their derivatives $\frac{\partial^{|j|} \varphi}{\partial x^{j_{1}} \cdots \partial x^{j_{d}}},|j| \leq 2$, are continuous and belong to the class $\mathbf{F}$, then the solution to the system of elliptic PDEs (5.3) satisfies the following estimate for some $\kappa \geq 1$ [6, Chap. 9, Sec. 7]:

$$
\sum_{|j|=0}^{4}\left|\frac{\partial^{|j|}}{\partial x^{j_{1}}, \ldots, \partial x^{j_{d}}} u(x ; m)\right| \leq K\left(1+|x|^{\kappa}\right)
$$

where $K>0$ does not depend on $x$. The Poisson equation can be used in proving properties of the time-averaging estimator $\hat{\varphi}^{e r g}$ analogously to [17] (see also [12, 2]).

abstract:
It is proposed to use stochastic differential equations with state-dependent
switching rates (SDEwS) for sampling from finite mixture distributions. An
Euler scheme with constant time step for SDEwS is considered. It is shown that
the scheme converges with order one in weak sense and also in the ergodic
limit. Numerical experiments illustrate the use of SDEwS for sampling from
mixture distributions and confirm the theoretical results.
